text:
Washington Street, north from W. Houston Street, showing mainly the west side of this thoroughfare. In the foreground are a row of stables extending to Clarkson Street. In 1930 these buildings will be razed for the St. Johns Park Freight Terminal; this site being the proposed northern portion of same.

Buildings north of Clarkson Street will be demolished at same time and the elevated roadbed of the New York Central Railroad erected there. The street car tracks shown will be removed by the W.P.A. in 1937.

View No. 3 shows buildings at the N.W. corner of Washington (right) and W. Houston (left) Streets.

View 1: May 12, 1927
View 2: July 25, 1930
View 3: Oct. 21, 1927

P. L. Sperr

P. L. Sperr

(1)
Washington Street, from West Houston (formerly Hammersley) Street to King Street, east side, seen from cleared west side.  In the background the Standard Statistics Building, on the west side of Hudson Street from King to Charlton Streets, is shown under construction.
September 30, 1930.
P.L. Sperr.

(2)
The same, a little over five weeks later.
November, 8, 1930.
P.L. Sperr.

(1)
Washington Street, from West Houston (formerly Hammersley) Street to King Street, east side, seen from cleared west side.  In the background the Standard Statistics Building, on the west side of Hudson Street from King to Charlton Streets, is shown under construction.
September 30, 1930.

(2)
The same, a little over five weeks later.
November, 8, 1930.
P.L. Sperr.

Washington Street, west side, from West Houston (formerly Hammersley) Street to Clarkson Street, inclusive.
September 30, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)
Washington Street, west side, from West Houston (formerly Hammersley) Street to Leroy Street, inclusive.
September 30, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same, to Leroy Street and north. The northern end of the new St. John's Park Freight Terminal will be at Clarkson Street, but the buildings on the west side of Washington Street north from that point are being razed for the building of the railroad's elevated roadbed.
June 30, 1931.

P. L. Sperr.

June 30, 1931.

P. L. Sperr.
